sections.title: About You
sections.subtitle: Let's start with some basic information

questions.question: What name would you like us to use?
What is your due date?
Who is your healthcare provider?
Who will be supporting you during labor?
questions.learnMore: Having continuous support during labor has been shown to [improve outcomes and satisfaction](https://www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD003766.pub6/full). Support people can help with comfort measures, advocacy, and emotional encouragement.

questions.question: Is there anything special we should know about you?
questions.placeholder: Cultural preferences, medical conditions, past experiences, fears, etc.
questions.learnMore: This helps your care team provide personalized support. Feel free to share any cultural traditions, past birth experiences, anxiety concerns, or medical conditions that might affect your care.

sections.title: Labor Preferences
sections.subtitle: How would you like your labor environment?

questions.question: What environment preferences do you have for labor?
questions.learnMore: Creating a calm, comfortable environment can help you relax and allow labor to progress naturally. The nursing staff will do their best to accommodate your preferences.

questions.question: What are your preferences for movement during labor?
questions.learnMore: [Movement during labor](https://www.acog.org/womens-health/faqs/labor-induction) can help manage pain and may help your baby move into the best position. Options may be limited if you have an epidural or continuous fetal monitoring is needed.

options.label: Move freely - walk, use birth ball, change positions
Some movement with guidance from staff

questions.question: What are your preferences for eating and drinking during labor?
questions.learnMore: [Clear liquids are typically allowed](https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/2009/05/oral-intake-during-labor) during labor for low-risk patients. Some hospitals allow light snacks during early labor. IV fluids are available if needed.

options.label: Clear liquids only (water, ice chips, popsicles)

questions.question: What are your preferences for fetal monitoring?
questions.learnMore: [Continuous monitoring](https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/practice-bulletin/articles/2009/07/intrapartum-fetal-heart-rate-monitoring-nomenclature-interpretation-and-general-management-principles) is required in certain situations (epidural, Pitocin, high-risk pregnancy). Intermittent monitoring may allow more freedom of movement for low-risk pregnancies.

questions.question: If induction becomes necessary, what are your preferences?
questions.learnMore: [Induction](https://www.acog.org/womens-health/faqs/labor-induction) may be recommended for medical reasons such as post-dates pregnancy, preeclampsia, or gestational diabetes. Methods include membrane sweeping, cervical ripening agents, and Pitocin.

options.label: Try natural methods first (walking, nipple stimulation)
Start with medical induction if recommended
Discuss options with me when the time comes

sections.title: Pain Management
sections.subtitle: How would you like to manage discomfort?

questions.question: What is your overall approach to pain management?
questions.learnMore: There's no right or wrong approach. Your comfort and ability to cope are what matter. You can always change your mind during labor. [ACOG states](https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/2017/10/approaches-to-limit-intervention-during-labor-and-birth) that maternal request is a sufficient reason for pain relief.

options.label: Prefer unmedicated birth - will request medication if needed
Wait and see - open to medication based on how labor progresses
Would like an epidural when appropriate
Would like an epidural as early as possible

questions.question: Which non-medical pain relief methods interest you?
questions.learnMore: These [non-pharmacologic techniques](https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/2017/10/approaches-to-limit-intervention-during-labor-and-birth) can be used alone or combined with medication. Your support person and nurses can help you with many of these techniques.

questions.question: Which medical pain relief options would you consider?
questions.learnMore: [Epidurals](https://www.acog.org/womens-health/faqs/medications-for-pain-relief-during-labor-and-delivery) are the most effective form of pain relief and allow you to rest. IV medications provide temporary relief but may make you drowsy. Nitrous oxide (laughing gas) provides mild relief with no lasting effects.

options.label: Prefer to avoid medical pain relief

questions.question: If you want an epidural, when would you like it?

sections.title: Delivery Preferences
sections.subtitle: Your preferences for the moment of birth

questions.question: What positions interest you for pushing?
questions.learnMore: [Different positions](https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/2017/10/approaches-to-limit-intervention-during-labor-and-birth) can help with comfort and may help your baby descend. Your ability to use certain positions may depend on whether you have an epidural.

options.label: Whatever feels right in the moment

questions.question: What type of pushing guidance would you prefer?
questions.learnMore: Directed pushing involves holding your breath and pushing for 10 seconds. [Spontaneous pushing](https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/2017/10/approaches-to-limit-intervention-during-labor-and-birth) follows your body's urges. Research shows both methods are safe.

options.label: Spontaneous pushing - follow my body's urges
No preference - trust my care team

questions.question: What are your preferences regarding episiotomy?
questions.learnMore: Episiotomy is a cut made to enlarge the vaginal opening. [Routine episiotomy is no longer recommended](https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/practice-bulletin/articles/2016/07/prevention-and-management-of-obstetric-lacerations-at-vaginal-delivery) by ACOG. It may be needed in emergencies.

options.label: Prefer to avoid unless medically necessary

questions.question: What would you like during the moment of birth?
questions.learnMore: These preferences help your care team know how you'd like to experience meeting your baby for the first time.

options.label: Use a mirror to see baby emerge
Touch baby's head as they crown
Keep the room calm and quiet

questions.question: What are your preferences for cord clamping?
questions.learnMore: [Delayed cord clamping](https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/2020/12/delayed-umbilical-cord-clamping-after-birth) (waiting 30-60 seconds) is recommended by ACOG for most births. It allows more blood to transfer to baby and has health benefits including improved iron stores. Immediate clamping may be needed in emergencies.

options.label: Delayed cord clamping (30-60 seconds or longer)

questions.question: Who would you like to cut the umbilical cord?

sections.title: Cesarean Preferences
sections.subtitle: In case a C-section is needed

questions.content: Even if you're planning a vaginal birth, it's helpful to think about your preferences in case a cesarean becomes necessary. [About 32% of births](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/fastats/delivery.htm) in the US are cesarean deliveries.

questions.question: Who would you like present during a cesarean?
What preferences do you have for a cesarean birth?
questions.learnMore: Many hospitals can accommodate '[gentle' or 'family-centered' cesarean](https://www.acog.org/womens-health/faqs/cesarean-birth) preferences when it's safe to do so. Ask your provider what options are available.

options.label: Lowered drape to see baby born

questions.question: Anesthesia preferences for cesarean:
questions.learnMore: [Regional anesthesia](https://www.acog.org/womens-health/faqs/cesarean-birth) (spinal or epidural) is preferred for most cesareans as it allows you to be awake. General anesthesia is used in emergencies or when regional isn't possible.

sections.title: Newborn Care
sections.subtitle: Preferences for your baby's first hours

questions.question: What are your preferences for skin-to-skin contact?
questions.learnMore: [Skin-to-skin contact](https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/infant-and-young-child-feeding) helps regulate baby's temperature, heart rate, and breathing. It also promotes bonding and breastfeeding. The [AAP and WHO recommend](https://publications.aap.org/pediatrics/article/150/1/e2022057988/188304/Breastfeeding-and-the-Use-of-Human-Milk) immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin for at least an hour after birth.

options.label: Partner does skin-to-skin if I can't

questions.question: When would you like baby's first bath?
questions.learnMore: Delaying the first bath (24+ hours) helps maintain baby's temperature, blood sugar, and allows the vernix to absorb into the skin. The [World Health Organization recommends](https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241506649) waiting at least 24 hours after birth.

questions.question: How do you plan to feed your baby?
questions.learnMore: Whatever your choice, the nursing staff will support you. [Lactation consultants](https://www.acog.org/clinical/clinical-guidance/committee-opinion/articles/2021/02/breastfeeding-and-lactation-support) are available to help with breastfeeding challenges.

questions.question: What feeding support would you like?

options.label: No formula or pacifiers unless medically needed
Okay to supplement with formula if needed

questions.question: Standard newborn procedures - please indicate any you'd like to discuss or decline:
questions.learnMore: These procedures are routine but can be discussed with your provider. [Vitamin K](https://www.cdc.gov/breastfeeding-special-circumstances/hcp/illnesses-conditions/vitamin-k.html) prevents a rare but serious bleeding disorder. [Eye ointment](https://www.aap.org/en/patient-care/newborn-and-infant-health/) prevents infection. The [hepatitis B vaccine](https://www.cdc.gov/hepatitis-b/hcp/vaccination-infants-children/birth-dose-information.html) is the first in a series recommended by CDC.

questions.question: If you have a boy, what are your circumcision preferences?
questions.learnMore: Circumcision is an elective procedure. There are medical benefits and risks to consider. The [American Academy of Pediatrics](https://publications.aap.org/pediatrics/article/130/3/e756/30225/Male-Circumcision) states the health benefits outweigh the risks, but the benefits are not great enough to recommend routine circumcision for all male newborns.

options.label: No, we do not want circumcision

questions.question: What are your rooming preferences?
questions.learnMore: [Rooming-in](https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/infant-and-young-child-feeding) means baby stays with you 24/7. This promotes bonding and breastfeeding. The nursery is available if you need rest.

options.label: Baby in nursery at night for rest
Flexible based on how I'm feeling

questions.question: What are your preferences for visitors?

options.label: Limited visitors - need rest and bonding time
Flexible - will decide based on how I feel

questions.question: Photo and social media preferences:

options.label: Photos okay but no social media
Photos and social media sharing okay

questions.question: Discharge timing preferences:
questions.learnMore: Typical hospital stay is [1-2 days for vaginal birth and 2-4 days for cesarean](https://www.acog.org/womens-health/faqs/hospital-stay-after-delivery). Early discharge may be possible if you and baby are doing well.

options.label: Prefer to go home as soon as possible
Would like to stay longer if possible

questions.question: What postpartum support would you like to learn about?
Anything else you'd like your care team to know?
questions.placeholder: Any other preferences, concerns, or special requests...
